awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A unique window into the ecology of Cretaceous forests during the rise of angiosperms
awd_abstract_narration:
Flowering plants first appeared approximately 140 million years ago, during the age of dinosaurs. Flowering plants rapidly diversified and spread around the globe and evolved a variety of life forms that added to the ecological complexity of forests. This project investigates a crucial interval of this transition, ~75 million years ago, by studying a series of exceptionally preserved fossil floras from southern New Mexico, which existed under a wet tropical paleoclimate. These studies will provide important insights into forest evolution in tropical climates, the timing and patterns of ecological expansion of flowering plants, the habitats of dinosaurs and early mammals, and the history of vegetation for the western interior of North America. Most of these plant fossils collected this research represent species new to science and can provide important historical records for living lineages. The project provides training for students from diverse backgrounds. It also has several major initiatives for education and public outreach, including the development, testing, and dissemination of lesson plans for science teachers about the rise of flowering plants and modern forests. 

This project will use extensive paleontological field studies, fossil collections, and new quantitative techniques to generate extensive reconstructions of late Campanian forests from fossilized leaves, wood, seeds and fruits. By using newly developed sampling and analytical techniques, these studies will generate reconstructions of the diversity and ecological structure of the paleo forests. The fossil floras are from the Jose Creek Member of the McRae Formation in south-central New Mexico, which was located >200 km inland of the Western Interior Seaway. The diversity and community structure of the fossil forests will be reconstructed using spatial distributions of plant species across the landscape, while the functional ecology of the plants will be reconstructed by measuring traits of leaves, wood, and seeds/fruits that are reflective of life form, physiology, growth rate, and reproductive strategy. This information, when combined with analyses of climatically similar Cretaceous, Cenozoic, and extant floras, will be used to test hypotheses about: 1) the community structure and roles of major clades in Campanian floras; 2) the functional ecology of Cretaceous angiosperms; and 3) how the ecological structure of forests has changed through time in warm-wet climates. The functional trait-based approach used will link extant and paleo-ecology, and have broad applicability to understanding ecological radiations and community turnover following key evolutionary innovations.

por.por_cntn:
During the Cretaceous period, flowering plants rapidly diversified and took on many new roles in land ecosystems, resulting in the dawn of the compositionally and structurally modern forest ecosystems that we know today. However, the timing and patterns of change across landscapes remains incompletely known. In part, this is because the plant fossil record is both temporally and geographically incomplete, which makes the study of plant evolution and the role of different plant groups in continental ecosystems difficult. More problematic still: the plant fossil record is very biased by the environments that are most commonly preserved, which are typically in or close to wet areas where sediments accumulate (coastlines, streams, lakes). The 76-million-year-old fossil Jose Creek Flora (JCF), frozen in time in a volcanic ash deposit named Dori’s Tuff, is one of the rare exceptions. It was located about 200km inland of a sea that cut through the Western Interior of North America during the Cretaceous, and thus contains a forest community representing an inland, rather than coastal or wetland region. Furthermore, it was further south and grew under warmer (tropical) conditions than most other coeval fossil floras from North America. Lastly, the fossil deposit containing the JCF is unusually extensive – the fossil-rich volcanic tuff can be traced for 1.2 km, allowing us to reconstruct a vegetational transect through an ancient forest and assess the spatial distribution of its inhabitants. In total, the Jose Creek Flora (JCF) offered a peek into what paleobotanists usually miss out on and consequently revealed a range of very surprising outcomes.

The JCF is among the earliest floras from the Western Interior to demonstrate ecological dominance of flowering plants across the landscape; they comprised 89% all species and more than 80% of plant cover. The so-called dicot flowering plants were the most abundant, but monocot groups such as palms and gingers were prominent across the understory to midstory. Despite the dominance of flowering plant species, conifers still played an important role in a mixed conifer-angiosperm canopy, with a new species of redwood being the most commonly occurring species across the transect. The JCF also turned out to be one of the most diverse fossil floras so far recorded from the Cretaceous (145-66 million years ago), with more than 200 different leaf ‘morphotypes’ thought to likely represent different plant species, most of which have never been described or reported. Comparisons with other fossil floras demonstrate that the southern parts of the Western Interior appear to be far more diverse than fossil floras from more northern regions during the Late Cretaceous (100.5-66 million years ago) and even later in the Paleocene (66-56 million years ago). The vast majority of the species were only found in three or less of the 26 quarries, illustrating an early high level of spatial heterogeneity that is common in modern diverse tropical forests.

Besides leaves, branches, tree trunks and even flowers, the JCF has yielded many fossilized diaspores. These are the dispersal units that plants make after reproduction, such as seeds and fruits. Interestingly we found that JCF diaspores come in a wide range of sizes, and the size of the larger ones is significantly greater than those from contemporaneous fossil plant deposits. This large range of sizes and morphologies of diaspores reveals that flowering plants in the JCF had diverse reproductive and dispersal strategies, much wider than previously known for the Cretaceous—more akin to more modern floras.

All our finds revealed how flowering plants achieved much more diverse ecologies and ecological dominance in tropical climate regions earlier than previously thought during the Cretaceous. By providing a window into an underrepresented environment, the JCF has provided a significant step in understanding the variation in vegetation structure and composition across different habitats and environments in the Late Cretaceous. This work ultimately contributes to a recently developing paradigm shift in how we view the role and diversity of early flowering plant lineages.

This project involved eighteen undergraduate and two graduate students, who performed the research and were trained in research aspects from fossil collecting to the laboratory and museum. Students presented their research at professional conferences, universities and were engaged in public outreach. This body of research has generated two doctoral theses which will form the basis for additional peer-reviewed publications. Over 5,000 specimens have been collected, were curated and are permanently reposited at the UC Museum of Paleontology and Perot Museum of Nature and Science (PMNS) for research and education for future generations. In conjunction with scientific reports, lesson plans for teachers were produced with learning activities based on the JCF and disseminated and used in Bay Area Scientists Inspiring Students program and the PMNS Whynauts series. The project team has also worked to develop data-informed illustrative reconstructions of the remarkable flora to enhance communication to the public and future exhibits.
